text:
Using Plots.jl it is easy enough to generate a plot with Time on the horizontal axis, but trying to apply a value for `xlimits` it fails - below I include a small test case the the first lines of the error message.  Anyone know of a work around?
```using Dates, Plots

x = rand(100)
t0 = Time(1,10,13)
tlist = [t0+i*Second(1) for i in 1:100]

p=plot(tlist,x,xlimits=(tlist[5],tlist[20]))```
This gives:
```Error showing value of type Plots.Plot{Plots.GRBackend}:
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching Float64(::Time)
Closest candidates are:
  Float64(::Irrational{:catalan}) at irrationals.jl:189
  Float64(::UInt32) at float.jl:66
  Float64(::Bool) at float.jl:66
.....```

text: `xrange`doesn’t seem to work either, but in this particular case you can do `plot(tlist[5:20],x[5:20])` .

elements.text: doesn’t seem to work either, but in this particular case you can do

text:
Unfortunately this doesn’t help - the problem is that when you do this, the plot still has a bit of buffer space to the left and right of the values in the line.   The x-axis doesn’t have the required range.  In my application, I will be displaying the plot over a heatmap so that I have to be able to control the displayed range on the x-axis so that they are the same.

However, I’ve found that I can get the desired behavior changing the time values to `DateTimes` , in which case one can control the `xlimits`.  Now I have to play with `xformatter` (I think) to get tick labels displayed without the date…
